subject: Make flavors is_public option actually work
commit_message:
Make flavors is_public option actually work

When you create a flavor, you can set an is_public flag to be True or
False.  It is True by default.  When False, the intention is that the
flavor is only accessible by an admin, unless you use the flavor_access
API extension to grant access to specific tenants.

Unfortunately, the only place in the code where this was being enforced
was when listing flavors through the API.  It would filter out the
non-public ones for a non-admin.  Otherwise, the flavor was accessible.
You could get the details, and you could boot an instance with it, if
you figured out a valid flavor ID.

This patch adds enforcement down in the db layer.  It also fixes one
place in the API where the context wasn't passed down to enable the
enforcement to happen.

Fix bug 1194093.

(cherry picked from commit b65d506a5f9d9b2b20777a9aceb44a8ffed6a5de)

In the iptables firewall driver, each port method (update_port_filter,

subject: Fix race between aggregate list and delete
commit_message:
Fix race between aggregate list and delete

Previously, during get_aggregate_list() if an aggregate was deleted
after the list of aggregates is initially read from the database
with db.get_aggregate_all() then the list method would raise an
AggregateNotFound when it called _get_aggregates_info(), which makes
additional db queries for each aggregate. This would result in the api
request receiving a 404 response. However db.get_aggregate_all()
already contained all the required information for the aggregate
list.

This commit changes renames _get_aggregate_info() to
_reformat_aggregate_info() which just correctly parse the response of
db.get_aggregate_get() and formats its response in the same way as
_get_aggregates_info() would return with the extra database queries.
This fixes the race condition not only in list but potentially in
other calls by only making one database read for any get operation.

Also, the unit tests added in this commit are to fill a coverage gap
with get_aggregate_list() and to ensure that we don't change the
behavior of list while fixing the race condition. The race condition
is not directly testable in unit tests because it requires a
multithreaded environment to send a delete immediately after a list
call. It was uncovered by running tempest in parallel with testr.

Fixes bug 1204598

subject: Implements new metadata endpoint
commit_message:
Implements new metadata endpoint

This patchset removes the ability to specify metadata when creating a
queue as per the Marconi Weekly Meeting held on July 18th, 2013.

It also adds a new endpoint: /v1/queues/{name}/metadata with operations
- GET
- PUT

Removes:
- GET /v1/queues/{queue_name}  # replaced by metadata ^^
- the request body from PUT /v1/queues/{queue_name}

Rationale:

The addition of the metadata endpoint increases the extensibility of
the API, and decouples metadata updates from queue creation. This
makes it easier for us in the future to add other endpoints, say
/v1/queues/{name}/config for modifying special values that change the
behavior of the queue.

With that addition, creating a queue with metadata became slightly
more dangerous. In the case where a user accidentally tries to create
a queue that already exists, the metadata for the existing queue would
be overwritten by the PUT request body. By removing the ability to
modify metadata at queue creation time, it also prevents these types
of accidents.

Tests:

New unit tests added to capture expected behavior. Old tests were also
updated to reflect new endpoint and behavior.

Storage API changes:
- storage(queue): get -> get_metadata

subject: Implement l3 agent dual-NAT mode support
commit_message:
Implement l3 agent dual-NAT mode support

blueprint l3-dual-nat-mode

With dual-NAT mode enabled, each router has a 'private' gateway port,
which is not maintained by Quantum. All those gateway ports of the
routersin a l3 agent are bridged to br-ex and belong to the same
local subnet (e.g. 169.254.4.0/24). The subnet's gateway is another
tap device in the network node host and bridged to br-ex as well.
There will be two NAT ops when a VM accesses outside network, one is
between tenant network and "private" subnet, the other is between
"private" subnet and dest netowrk.

Dual-NAT mode could bring two benefits:
* Reduce the usage of public IP address, especially if muti-host
  feature is available
* VMs can access all networks could be accessed by network node host
